author: Dan Moran
title: True blue Cub fans' wild 500mile tale to see history happen at Wrigleyville - Lake County News-Sun
text:
For Wrigley Field, it was a march of 101 years to reach the moment when the old ballyard would witness a postseason series-clinching victory for the Chicago Cubs.
For Glenview native Doug Maier, witnessing that moment involved a same-day drive back and forth from his current home in East Lansing, Mich., to be part of the maelstrom at Clark and Addison — and then get his son back in time for Wednesday morning classes at Michigan State University.
We'll call it "Operation 500 Miles to History." Or semi-history, since the Cubs have hopefully not yet begun to fight and win.
As Maier told the tale early Wednesday — but not too early, considering he had arrived home well after the witching hour — the adventure was a perfect confluence of events that began by winning the lottery. Not the lottery with a capital "L," but the one sponsored by the Cubs to secure postseason tickets at face value.
Both he had his 18-year-old son, Steven, had thrown their names in the ring, but only Steven was selected — and he found out about it only after checking his email a day after the winners were notified.
But that would turn out to be a blessing. After logging in to buy tickets for Monday's Game 3, Maier said "we made a couple of mistakes on the website" that bumped their options down to standing room only. They moved on to buy seats for Game 4, which at that point was an "if necessary" game.

(Denys Bucksten) A few clicks later, they had three lower-deck seats for about $100 each. Maier immediately checked an aftermarket website to learn that similar seats were already going for $300. They would be going for $400 after the Cubs won games two and three to force a fourth game.
Then the fated date arrived. Maier and his son left mid-Michigan at 8 a.m. Central, arrived in Schaumburg to pick up his mom — your basic long-suffering Cub fan — around noon, headed straight for Wrigleyville and drove the 30 miles in the 90 minutes they had expected.
The path to glory continued with finding a free parking space a half-mile east of the park through "a guy who knows a guy," catching a quick bite at Wrigley BBQ on Broadway, and getting inside the Friendly Confines with no security hassles despite a backpack full of water and beef jerky.
And then there was the game experience itself. Singer John Vincent performing what Maier called "the greatest rendition of the National Anthem I've ever heard." Javy Baez hitting an early three-run bomb that produced a head-numbing roar. All 42,000 fans going into a frenzy with the final out just after sunset.

(Brian Cassella) The Maiers lingered to enjoy the moment, but not too long. They were on the road from Schaumburg by 8:30 p.m. and back in East Lansing at 12:30 a.m. without a moving violation. Mission truly accomplished.
"The biggest thing I thought about was, 'I get to share this with my mom, and she's a lifelong Cub fan,'" Maier said, "and then my son is 18 and has grown up in Michigan but still considers Chicago his home.
"So the fact that all those things came together is amazing," he added. "Even the weather — I mean, there was nothing that went wrong."
Here's hoping that smooth sailing continues for about the next two weeks.
